title: 'Fake' loan document found during Hutson raid
text:
The then 460-centre outfit had launched a takeover of rival Affinity Education, which ultimately failed. The hearing is testing evidence alleging that Ms Hutson arranged for G8 to fund another businessman, Nigel Elias, to acquire $8.5 million worth of shares in Affinity. Mr Elias has not been charged.

The court has heard allegations that Ms Hutson had implemented a “dishonest scheme” so it appeared G8 had lent money to another organisation, called Ingenious Communications. Ingenious would then allegedly pretended to onlend funds to Mr Elias’s company.

Neil Clelland, QC, representing Ms Hutson, argued his client had been charged for giving false evidence on the basis she gave a different version of events to Mr Elias, and any suggestion she was lying was to be “proven by what Mr Elias says”.

But Mr Bastianon maintained ASIC had relied on more than Mr Elias’s words.

“At the meeting at [Sydney’s] Intercontinental Hotel, Mr Elias says that Ms Hutson handed over a loan agreement between Ingenious Communications and Nigel Elias. Nigel Elias says, ‘I’ve never seen that document before’. He says it was handed to him by Ms Hutson at that meeting," Mr Bastianon said.

“Ms Hutson, when we examined her, said, ‘Yes I met with Mr Elias but I didn’t hand over any of those documents, I know nothing about any loan agreement between Ingenious and Mr Elias. We talked about other matters.’

“Subsequently … we found a copy of those documents at Ms Hutson's home when we executed a search warrant. Now that evidence supports Mr Elias's version of events, and rebuts Ms Hutson’s.”

Mr Clelland repeatedly quizzed Mr Bastianon on whether ASIC had used in mid-2016 its powerful Section 19 powers – under which people must answer questions even if they cannot be used in evidence against them – to try and figure out any defences she might have.

Advertisement

Ms Hutson had just rejected a request to come in for an official interview, at which she could decline to answer questions. “The very next day she received a compulsory notice to undergo a section 19 examination,” Mr Clelland said.

He aired in court an April email from Ms Bastianon, before the examination, which said: “We will need of course to examine Hutson and then review her evidence to see what holes need to be covered as a result of what we are told and to assess any possible defences.”

Mr Bastianon denied ASIC had been trying to cover off any defences in a prosecution case, saying the regulator would want to know if there were any explanations consistent with innocence about the transactions.

The use of the examination power was proper and ASIC had not formed a final view about any prosecution of Ms Hutson then, he told court.

Mr Bastianon said ASIC had suspected Ms Hutson had committed an offence, and had evidence to recommend charges.

Examination transcript contents were provided to prosecutors, he said.

He is on the stand on Friday with another ASIC investigator to be called.
description: But ASIC's use of compulsory interrogation powers is coming under the microscope in the hearing for star merchant banker Jenny Hutson.
